abstract.p: Synthetic dye wastewater is a significant environmental concern, particularly due to its extensive usage in industries such as textiles, printing, and dyeing. Traditional methods for treating wastewater with synthetic dyes are often seen as costly and inefficient, primarily because of the dyes’ robust chemical nature. In light of these challenges, there has been a growing interest in recent years in the use of biodegradation. This method utilizes specific microorganisms capable of breaking down these stubborn pollutants, offering a more sustainable and effective solution for their removal. Given the limited detailed studies on the bacterial decolorization of oil-soluble (solvent-soluble) azo dyes, there is a significant need to address this issue. The ability of salt-tolerant bacteria named Halomonas strain A3 to decolorize an oil soluble azo dye, Toluidine Red was investigated. Decolorization conditions, including initial dye concentration, pH, NaCl percent (w/v), and incubation temperature, were optimized using the one-factor-at-a-time method with dye as the sole carbon and energy source. The ultraviolet-visible spectrophotometric method, high-performance liquid chromatography, and gas chromatography mass spectrometry analyses were used to investigate the decolorization mechanism at optimum condition, including 25 ppm dye concentration, 5% (w/v) NaCl, pH 6.5, and incubation temperature of 35 °C. Compared to the parent dye, the ultraviolet-visible scan of the supernatant suggested that the degradation mechanism was the main reason for color removal rather than inactive surface adsorption. HPLC analysis confirmed this conclusion. The final compounds produced from TR degradation were identified as benzene diazonium (m/z 105 ± 1) and 3-Phenyl-acrylic acid (m/z 149 ± 1). According to the results, Halomonas strain A3 is a practical alternative for degrading effluents containing oil-soluble azo dyes in salty conditions. A pathway for dye degradation was predicted based on the obtained intermediate and final products.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Azo o dyes are a class of synthetic dyes characterized by the presence of one or more azo (–N = N) linkages attached to aromatic rings. Representing the largest portion of dyes used in industry, they constitute approximately 60–70% of all synthetic dyes1.

Among them, oil-soluble azo dyes are specifically formulated to dissolve in oils and organic solvents rather than in water. These dyes are widely utilized across industries such as plastics, cosmetics, and food manufacturing, where compatibility with lipid-based materials is necessary2. In contrast to water-soluble dyes, which disperse readily in aqueous media, oil-soluble dyes interact preferentially with non-polar solvents, making them particularly suitable for applications requiring resistance to moisture3.

The management of effluents containing synthetic dyes from various industrial sources remains a significant challenge, with the issue of colored wastewater pollution intensifying in numerous countries4. The persistence and non-biodegradable characteristics of these discharged dyes lead to substantial environmental concerns5,6.

Although numerous chemical and physical techniques exist for dye removal, conventional methods are generally unsuitable for the treatment of colored wastewater. These approaches are often costly, inefficient, and generate sludge by-products, which contribute to further environmental pollution7–9. Biological treatment methods are considered promising due to their eco-friendliness, low sludge generation, cost-effectiveness, and minimal energy requirements10–12. Effective microbial degradation of dyes can achieve complete mineralization while reducing sludge production. Nevertheless, despite these advantages, several challenges persist. High salinity levels, the presence of oil-soluble azo dyes, and their associated metal complexes in many industrial effluents often limit the effectiveness of conventional biological treatments, making it difficult to maintain optimal conditions. A major obstacle in the biodegradation of solvent-soluble dyes is their compatibility with non-aqueous solvent systems. The greater mobility of water-soluble azo dyes in the medium, along with their easier penetration through cell walls, facilitates their degradation, making their treatment less challenging than that of oil-soluble azo dyes13–16. Halo-tolerant and halophilic bacteria can withstand substantial concentrations of toxic metals in their environment, rendering them highly effective for treating oil- and oxyanion-contaminated effluents17–19. Therefore, given the high salinity and osmotic pressure characteristic of azo dye-containing wastewaters, employing halophilic or halotolerant microorganisms represents a practical, rational, and innovative approach for their remediation. Although several studies have examined the ability of halotolerant bacteria to decolorize and degrade water-soluble azo dyes, investigations on insoluble or solvent-soluble azo dyes remain very limited20–23.Recognizing this gap, the present study explores the potential of Halomonas strain A3 to decolorize Toluidine Red, an oil-soluble azo dye, under high-salt conditions.

This study examined the capacity of Halomonas strain A3 to degrade Toluidine Red (TR), an oil-soluble azo dye. The decolorization process was optimized by varying dye concentration, pH, salinity, and temperature using a one-factor-at-a-time (OFAT) approach. The chemical intermediates formed during biodegradation were characterized through high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), ultraviolet-visible (UV-Vis) spectroscopy, and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS). The findings indicate the potential of Halomonas strain A3 for effective TR degradation.

sec.title: Microorganism and culture condition
sec.p: Halomonas strain A3 (GenBank accession no. DQ372909) was received from Tehran University, Iran (Laboratory of Extremophiles, School of Biology). Asad et al. have reported details of the strain’s isolation and identification17. Based on their report, the isolate shared the main phenotypic features of the genus Halomonas and showed 99% similarity to Halomonas meridiana.
Nutrient agar media supplemented with 7.5% (w/v) NaCl at 35 °C was used for the growth of a pure culture which was stored at 4 °C and sub-cultured periodically once in two weeks.

sec.title: Chemicals
sec.p: Toluidine Red (Pigment Red 3, C.I. No. 12120) was supplied from Ciba Geigy GmbH representative in Iran (CIBA). Since the dye was insoluble in water, Dimethylformamide (DMF) was used as the solvent. Tween 80 was used as the surfactant to decrease the adverse effects of the insolubility of the dye. Acetonitrile used in HPLC analysis was of HPLC grade. All the chemicals and reagents were of the highest purity and used without further purification. Figure 1 shows the Chemical structure of TR.

sec.title: Decolorization media
sec.p: The composition of the minimal medium used in dye decolorization experiment was as follows (g/l): KNO3: 5, (NH4)2SO4: 1, K2HPO4.3H2O: 0.87, KH2PO4: 0.54, MgSO4.7H2O: 0.2, CaCl2.2H2O: 0.02, FeSO4.7H2O: 0.01, MnSO4.H2O:0.005, supplemented with 2.5%−10% NaCl. Bacterial strain used dye as the source of carbon and energy. The medium was prepared according to the method prescribed in the Handbook of Microbiological Media24.

sec.title: Preparation of dye stock solution
sec.p: The dye stock solution was prepared by dissolving dye powder in Dimethylformamide (DMF) as solvent (1 mg/ml), using an ultrasonic bath. Tween 80 was added to the dye stock solution as a nonionic surfactant to reduce the negative consequences of dye insolubility.

Different concentrations of Tween 80 (0.10%, 0.25%, 0.3%, 0.5% and 0.75% (v/v)) were added to the dye stock solution, and the optimal surfactant concentration was determined based on the higher solubility. The best solubility of dye was obtained at 0.25% (v/v) of Tween 80, which was kept constant during the experiment. The dye stock solution was autoclaved separately. It should be considered the dye may be broken after autoclaving. It is better to filtrate the dye.

sec.title: Optimization of parameters for decolorization of dye
sec.p: Sterilized 35 mL glass tubes containing 15 mL of minimal medium were inoculated with 1% (v/v) of a bacterial suspension (1.5 × 10⁸ CFU mL⁻¹) prepared in distilled water with 7.5% (w/v) NaCl. The pH was controlled by 1 N NaOH and 1 N HCl before autoclaving, and incubation was done at static condition. The decolorization performance was optimized using the one-factor-at-a-time (OFAT) method, which is based on varying one parameter at a time and retaining the pre-optimized at a constant level. Different process parameters such as dye concentration (10 to 25 ppm), pH (4.5 to 10.5), NaCl percentage (2.5 to 10% (w/v), and incubation temperature (25 to 40 °C) were optimized with the basic conditions of 25 ppm dye, pH 8.5, 5% (w/v) NaCl, and 35 °C temperature.

sec.title: Decolorization measurement
UV-Vis spectral evaluation
sec.p: The Quality of decolorization was monitored using UV-Vis spectra of dye from 200 to 800 nm. Samples were withdrawn from the incubated medium at regular time intervals, and the supernatants were scanned using a spectrophotometer equipped with quartz cells (1cm3) after centrifuging at 7500 rpm for 5 min in a micro refrigerated centrifuge. The detection of any transformation of medium compounds was checked qualitatively by comparing the control and sample UV-Vis spectra.

sec.title: HPLC and GC-MS evaluation
sec.p: The 5-ml samples were extracted from the culture with two equal volumes of Ethyl Acetate. Extracts were evaporated to dryness in a rotary evaporator and the remaining solvent was dried overnight at room temperature. The residue was dissolved in 0.5 ml HPLC grade Acetonitrile and used for HPLC and GC-MS evaluations. HPLC analysis was performed on a symmetry C18 column with a dimension of 406 mm × 250 mm (Knauer, K2500, Germany) using Acetonitrile: water containing 0.1% Formic acid (50:50) as mobile phase at 1 ml/min for 10 min and UV detector at 254 nm at room temperature. The degradation products were identified using the GC-MS. The GC-MS evaluation of metabolites was performed using an HP6890 GC coupled with a HP-5973 MS detector (Hewllet Packard, USA). Gas chromatography was done with an HP-5MS column (30 m long×0.25 mm i.d) in a temperature programming mode. The initial column temperature was 60 °C, kept constant for 3 min. The final temperature was 250 °C held for 3 min. The increasing rate of temperature was 10 °C/min. Helium by 1 ml/min flow rate was used as carrier gas. The voltage of ionization was 70 eV. Degradation products were identified based on mass spectra and using the Wiley 275 spectral library stored in the computer software (Agilent Technologies, ChemStation software, version B.04.03, USA. URL: https://www.agilent.com/en/product/software-informatics/masshunter-suite/chemstation) of the GC-MS.
In this research, OFAT modeling and optimization were performed, and the degradation capacity was considered.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: The decolorization of oil-soluble dyes primarily involves physical and chemical mechanisms. Physically, the adsorption of dyes onto solid surfaces can lead to their removal. Processes such as oxidation, reduction, and hydrolysis play significant chemical roles. For example, advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) utilize reactive species to break down dye molecules. Biodegradation by microorganisms is another crucial mechanism, where specific strains can metabolize dye components, leading to their decolorization. The molecular structure of oil-soluble dyes significantly influences their decolorization efficiency. Factors such as the presence of functional groups, molecular weight, and the degree of conjugation affect the stability and reactivity of the dye. Dyes with more complex structures or extensive conjugated systems tend to show more resistance to decolorization. Understanding these structural characteristics is crucial for developing targeted strategies for effective dye removal and treatment. Environmental conditions, such as pH and temperature, together with the presence of catalysts, significantly impact the decolorization of oil-soluble dyes. For instance, an acidic or alkaline medium can enhance or inhibit certain chemical reactions involved in dye degradation. Elevated temperatures may increase reaction rates, facilitating faster decolorization. Additionally, metal ions or specific catalysts can enhance the efficiency of oxidation processes, leading to improved dye removal rates. Microbial decolorization offers several advantages over conventional chemical methods. Utilizing natural processes to break down harmful dyes is often more environmentally friendly. Microorganisms can achieve high selectivity for specific dyes, resulting in efficient degradation. Furthermore, microbial processes typically operate under milder conditions, reducing energy consumption and chemical waste. These attributes make microbial decolorization an attractive option for sustainable wastewater treatment practices. The efficacy of dye decolorization methods can be assessed through various analytical techniques. Spectrophotometry is commonly used to measure the absorbance of dye solutions before and after treatment, providing quantitative data on color removal. Additionally, chromatographic techniques can analyze the degradation products, helping to identify intermediate compounds formed during the process. Molecular analyses, such as DNA sequencing of microbial communities, can also provide insights into the biological pathways utilized for dye degradation.

sec.title: Using surfactant for decolorization experiment
sec.p: Surfactants can trap dye molecules within their hydrophobic cores by forming micelles around them. This mechanism makes the dyes more accessible for removal through biological decolorization25–27.
These compounds, which possess both hydrophilic and hydrophobic components, interact with dye molecules to enhance their solubility and accessibility for decolorization28.

This approach is particularly beneficial for treating industrial wastewater that contains hydrophobic or water-insoluble dyes. Due to the insoluble nature of the dye being studied (TR), employing surfactants was critically necessary. As a result, some surfactants like Sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS), Tween 80 and Tween 20 were evaluated, indicating the best results with Tween80, which was selected for use in this research29–31.

As mentioned in Sect. 2.1, the best surfactant performance was observed at the concentration of 0.25% (v/v). This means that 0.25% (v/v) was taken as the Critical Micelle Concentration (CMC) in which surface becomes saturated with surfactant molecules, and micelles start to form. After this point, the addition of surfactants will no longer affect the surface tension and is therefore unnecessary. However, it is important to note that while the solubility of the dye increases with surfactant concentration up to the critical micelle concentration (CMC), further increases beyond 0.25% (v/v) may not enhance solubility effectively. In fact, excessive surfactant concentrations can lead to micelle oversaturation or dye aggregation, which might reduce the bioavailability of the dye rather than its intrinsic solubility32,33. Additionally, high surfactant levels may alter medium properties such as viscosity or osmotic balance, indirectly affecting the overall decolorization efficiency. Therefore, 0.25% (v/v) was considered the optimal concentration for effective solubilization and biological accessibility of the dye34,35.
Mnif et al. (2022) used Tween 80 to accelerate enzymatic degradation in treatment of methyl Red in decolorization of methyl red using Bacillus thuringiensis RI1636.

sec.title: The effect of different parameters on decolorization of dye
sec.p: The decolorization ability of Halomonas strain A3 was studied at different initial concentrations of dye (10–25 ppm, pH 8.5, temperature 35 °C, 5% (w/v) NaCl), and the results were investigated up to 10 days of incubation (Fig. 2, Microsoft Excel 2019, URL: [https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/excel].

As the studied dye was insoluble in water, precipitation occurred at high concentrations of the dye, indicating that the dye can aggregate or precipitate at high concentrations, making it less accessible to microbial or enzymatic action. Thus, high dye concentrations were not investigated in this study, and it was proposed as a suggestion for researchers in future studies.

According to our results, increasing the initial dye concentration increased the decolorization percentage. The direct relationship between the color removal ability of bacteria and the dye concentration could be related to the fact that bacteria used dye as the source of carbon and energy, and as a result, the enzymatic activity increased with the increase of dye up to the concentration of 25 ppm.

At 25 ppm of TR, 58% decolorization was observed after 192 h of incubation. Similar observations were made earlier in the case of other dyes and strains37–39. Since pH plays a significant role in the transfer of cell materials across the membrane, it seems necessary to check the effect of this parameter on decolorization percent40.

The decolorization potential of Halomonas strain A3 was evaluated against various pH values. To investigate the effect of pH, similar decolorization media were made at different pH values with 25 ppm dye concentration and 5% (w/v) NaCl and incubated at 35 °C for 240 h (Fig. 3).

The maximum rate of TR decolorization was 66% at pH 6.5, 58% at pH 8.5, and 40% at pH 9.5. At highly acidic (pH 4.5) or alkaline (pH 10.5) conditions, decolorization efficiency was negligible. Previous studies reported that acidic and alkaline conditions have inhibitory effects on dye biodegradation, as protonation and deprotonation of azo dyes at highly acidic or alkaline conditions lead to changes in chemical structure, thereby reducing the ability of microorganisms to decolorize41,42. Based on the findings, the optimal pH for decolorization performance was 6.5 (66%), which can be justified as the maximum decolorization activity of bacterial cultures generally occurs at pH values near neutrality or slightly acidic43.

This result was similar to the results reported by Jadhav et al., who found the best pH for decolorization of direct red 5B with Comamonas sp. UVS was 6.538. Previous studies found that the highest ability of salt-tolerant bacteria, CAS, to decolorize K-2BP was observed in the pH range of 6–9 and temperature range of 30–37 °C44.
According to Ramaya et al.‘s report, the maximum decolorization of Acid Red by the Acinetobacter strain was observed in the pH range between 6 and 745.

In the range of 25 °C to 40 °C, the effect of temperature on dye removal was evaluated under pre-optimized pH (6.5) and dye concentration (25 ppm) with 5%(w/v) NaCl (Fig. 4). Results indicated that the color removal increased from 25 °C to 35 °C and then decreased slowly. The decolorization rate of TR with Halomonas strain A3 was 50% at 25 °C, 50% at 30 °C, 66% at 35 °C and 57% at 40 °C. The results indicated that 35 °C was the best temperature for decolorization, which could be attributed to the increase of bacterial growth and their enzymatic activity with the temperature. Qiu et al. (2022) reported that the decolorization rate of Direct Black G by Halophilic bacteria exceeded 98% at 30–40 °C46. Results of various studies on other dyes and microorganisms can be compared to our results47,48.

Decolorization of TR by Halomonas strain A3 was studied at various concentrations of NaCl (2.5–10% (w/v)), keeping the constant initial concentration of dye (25 ppm), pH (6.5), and temperature (35 °C). Considering the results, dye removal increased with increasing salinity from 2.5 to 5% (w/v) and then decreased. Decolorization was 53% when using 2.5% (w/v) NaCl and 47% when using 10% salt concentration. The optimum concentration of NaCl was 5% (w/v), in which 66% decolorization was observed after 240 h of incubation (Fig. 5). The inhibition effect at high salt concentrations (> 5% w/v) could be due to the negative influence of salt on the permeability of the cell membrane and relative competition between chloride and dye molecules for active sites of Halomonas strain A349,50. However, it is important to note that Toluidine Red is a non-ionic azo dye and does not directly compete with Cl⁻ ions for electrostatic binding sites. Instead, chloride exerts its effect through indirect mechanisms. Elevated chloride concentrations can modify the bacterial surface charge, thereby reduce electrostatic repulsion and alter dye–cell interactions51,52. In addition, the increase in ionic strength weakens hydrophobic interactions that normally facilitate the binding of hydrophobic dyes (salting-in or salting-out effect). Excess salinity also imposes osmotic stress, causing water efflux, cell shrinkage, and plasmolysis, which lower metabolic activity and enzymatic degradation efficiency. Moreover, Cl⁻ ions may alter membrane permeability, further decreasing dye uptake. These combined effects explain the reduced decolorization efficiency at NaCl concentrations higher than 5%53–55.

The inhibition effect at high salt concentrations (> 5%) could be due to the negative influence of salt on the permeability of cell membrane for dye ions and relative competition between chloride and dye molecules for active sites of Halomonas strain A3 at high salinity56–58.

The effects of elevated Cl⁻ includes modification of bacterial surface charge (reducing electrostatic repulsion) and increased ionic strength (weakening hydrophobic interactions), both influencing dye binding behavior. In hypertonic environments, the H2O will diffuse out from the cell, and the cell will dehydrate and shrink, ceasing cellular metabolism due to the plasmolysis phenomenon and adversely affecting the ability of several bacterial cells to tolerate high salt concentrations. A similar effect of salinity was seen in the decolorization of Direct Orange 16 by Micrococcus luteus59. In a study conducted by Emadi et al. (2021), decolorization efficiency reached 80% in the presence of 0–20 g/L of NaCl. In this article, osmotic pressure and plasmolysis were mentioned as factors leading to a reduction in bacterial decolorization at high salt concentrations60.

Previous studies reported that color removal decreased at salt concentrations more than 6% (w/v) in the decolorization of polar red b by Bacillus firmus56. According to the research conducted by Meng et al. on Acid Orange 27 (AO27) decolorization by Shewanella aquimarina, azoreductase activity and decolorization rate raised to 3% NaCl and a further increase in the concentration of NaCl resulted in a decrease in enzymatic activity and color removal rate, accordingly61. Research on insoluble azo dyes are limited. Chen et al. (2009) compared and investigated the ability of Lactobacillus acidophilus and Lactobacillus fermentum to decolorize a number of water-soluble and fat-soluble azo dyes62.

Also, Peng et al. (2019) investigated the effect of different parameters on the ability of strain ts17 bacteria to decolorize oil soluble azo dye called Sudan I and used DMSO as the solvent for mentioned dye13. Table 1 summarizes findings from previous studies on biological azo dye decolorization. While most reports focus on water-soluble types, research on water-insoluble dyes remains scarce.

sec.title: Decolorization manner of Halomonas strain A3
sec.p: This study analyzed decolorization manner qualitatively by monitoring with a UV-Vis spectrophotometer at optimum conditions (25ppm dye, pH 6.5, 5% (w/v) NaCl, and 35 °C). The control and decolorized samples were compared using UV-Vis spectral scans (200–800), as shown in Fig. 6. Surface adsorption or degradation mechanisms could be the reason for decolorization. In the case of adsorption, the UV-Vis absorption peaks decrease approximately relative to each other, but when decolorization occurs under the biodegradation mechanism, either the main visible light absorbance peak disappears or a new peak appears43,63.
The absorption spectrum of the supernatants at optimum conditions showed that the maximum visible light absorbance peak (λmax = 490 nm) was totally diminished and no new peaks appeared.

The conjugated structure of azo bond and amine groups were responsible for the red color of TR. The aromatic rings connected by the -N = N- bond were responsible for the emergence of the maximum absorption peak of TR at 490 nm (visible region).
The absorption spectrum in the sample supernatant showed noticeable changes, caused by a chemical change in the dye’s chemical structure and the azo group cleavage during dye decolorization.

This observation proves that the main mechanism and reason for color removal was the structural decomposition of the dye and not physical surface absorption. New metabolites containing aromatic amines were produced in the decolorizing medium due to dye breakage.

The changes in the UV-Vis spectrum suggest that new metabolites containing aromatic amines were produced in the decolorization medium due to dye breakdown, indicating that degradation (rather than physical surface adsorption) may govern the decolorization mechanism. But definitive confirmation requires further analyses, such as HPLC and GC-MS. Therefore, these tests were employed later in the study to conclusively determine the decolorization mechanism.

sec.title: HPLC analysis
sec.p: HPLC chromatogram of the initial sample at optimal condition showed two major peaks at retention times of 1.290 and 1.911 min and one shoulder peak at a retention time of 2.887 min.

After completing the decolorization process, some new peaks were observed due to biodegradation of the dye with three main peaks at 0.556 min, 1.292 min, and 2.86 min and two weak peaks at 3.719 and 4.646 min (Fig. 7). It has been shown that the biodegradation of azo dyes would produce aromatic and ionic byproducts. The lower aromaticity may result in the higher polarity of the components64. Moving the observed peaks before decolorization towards lower retention times in the decolorized sample (Rt = 0.556, 1.292, and 2.86), and also the formation of new peaks (Rt = 3.719 and 4.646) after decolorization, showed that new metabolites with higher polarity than the parent components were produced due to the breakdown of the dye structure.

caption.p: HPLC chromatogram of (a) control sample and (b) decolorized medium at optimum condition.

sec.title: Identification of metabolites from dye reduction at optimum conditions
sec.p: Figure 8 shows the gas chromatogram and mass spectral analysis of metabolites produced during dye degradation. The GC-MS analysis results revealed peaks whose molecular weight was lower than that of the control dye (Mw = 307). Based on the mass spectra of the produced intermediates and the chemical structure of the dye, the probable pathway was proposed in Fig. 9, showing various steps involved in TR degradation. The final product corresponding to the peak with a retention time of 7.2 min was identified as benzene diazonium (Mw = 105) with a molecular ion peak at m/z 105. The final metabolites detected in the mass spectra related to the peak with the retention time of 16.14 min were recognized as 3-phenyl acrylic acid with a molecular ion peak of 149.

Degradation of azo dyes can occur symmetrically or asymmetrically. In this study, the bond between the nitrogen of the azo group and the carbon of the 2-naphthol ring was broken as the first stage of dye decomposition.

Based on our observation, asymmetric cleavage of azo dye and then missing the NO2 group led to the formation of para methyl benzene diazonium at m/z 120 ± 1, which was subsequently demethylated to give benzene diazonium at m/z 105 (Fig. 9a). It was assumed that the asymmetric cleavage of azo dye resulted in the formation of intermediate metabolites 2-naphthol and then naphthalene 1,2- diol, which further underwent reduction to give rise to 2-(2-carboxy vinyl) benzoic acid. Finally, 3-Phenyl-acrylic acid fragment with mass peak (m/z) 149 was formed, which was the fragmentation product of 2-(2-carboxy vinyl) benzoic acid (Fig. 9b). The identified compounds suggested that Halomonas strain A3 might be a successful organism for degrading oil-soluble azo dye.

Tohamy et al. (2020), used a salt-tolerant yeast strain Sterigmatomyces halophilus for the Reactive Black 5 biodegradation. According to their study, asymmetric cleavage of azo bond was done, and the pathway was proposed based on the identified intermediates65. Emadi et al. (2022) used the combined application of biological-chemical treatment to degrade Acid Blue-113 to linear organic products66. The necessity of using two-stage degradation processes, including biological-chemical or biological aerobic-anaerobic or biological anoxic-anaerobic is strongly felt in cases where aromatic metabolites are formed during a single-step decolorization. In other words, complete detoxification of wastewaters containing azo dyes may require a two-step dyeing process.

Jonstrup et al. (2011) checked a sequential anaerobic-aerobic treatment of azo dyes and emphasized the need for a post-treatment to ensure complete amine degradation67. Also, the treatment of wastewater containing RB-5 was studied by Emadi et al. (2020), using the post-treatment process to convert the toxic aromatic amines compounds to those with lower toxicity68.

sec.p: It should be noted that the present study primarily investigated the degradation mechanism of Toluidine Red by Halomonas strain A3. However, decolorization is generally a combination of different processes, including adsorption on to dead or inactive cells, enzymatic degradation, and flocculation. Since adsorption experiments with dead cells were not carried out in this study, the relative contribution of adsorption to the overall decolorization process remains unknown. Future studies should evaluate the extent to which adsorption and flocculation contribute to the overall decolorization efficiency, with particular focus on comparing the performance of live and dead cells to provide a more comprehensive understanding of the decolorization mechanism.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The ability of Halomonas strain A3 was studied to decolorize and degrade an oil-soluble azo dye in the presence of Tween 80 as surfactant and dye as sole carbon source. The effect of various factors, including dye concentration, pH, temperature, and NaCl percent (w/v), on dye removal was investigated using the stepwise traditional methodology, one-factor-at-a-time method. The best decolorization was obtained at 25ppm dye, pH 6.5, 5% (w/v) salinity, and 35 °C incubation temperature. The mechanism by which Halomonas strain A3 removed color at optimum condition was investigated using spectrophotometric, HPLC, and GC-MS analyses. The final compounds formed from dye degradation appeared at m/z of 105 and 149, identified as benzene diazonium and 3-phenyl-acrylic acid, respectively.
Based on the GC-MS findings, Halomonas strain A3 is a potential organism for the treatment of the industrial wastewaters containing oil-soluble azo dyes in the presence of salt and toxic metals.

In summary, Halomonas strain A3 showed the ability to decolorize the model oil-soluble azo dye Toluidine Red under saline conditions, achieving about 60% efficiency. These results should be considered as a proof-of-concept, indicating the strain’s potential for treating saline and toxic wastewater. Future studies should evaluate its performance with diverse dyes and real industrial wastewater, and explore strategies such as microbial consortia, cell immobilization, and reactor optimization to enhance efficiency and industrial applicability.
